newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Czech minister to offer Budvar selloff plan-agency.
newsitem.headline: Czech minister to offer Budvar selloff plan-agency.

text.p: Czech Farm Minister Josef Lux will submit a plan to privatise the brewery Budvar n.p. before the end of 1996 now that trademark talks with Anheuser-Busch Cos collapsed, the CTK agency said on Tuesday.

It quoted Lux as saying no definite plan for the selloff was ready yet, but there was little chance that A-B would take part in the Ceske Budejovice (Budweis) brewery, seen by many Czechs as a piece of national heritage.

Lux said it was the Czech side, not Anheuser-Busch, which ended the talks over the use of the "Budweiser" and "Bud" trademarks -- which is prohibiting the rivals from selling their lables in the other's key markets, CTK reported.
He said that the Czechs registered "little positive attitude" from A-B's side.
The Saint Louis-based brewer on Monday said it ended talks with Czech Budvar on settling the lengthy dispute.
The Czech government has been mulling the privatisation of Budvar with and without participation of A-B, but had held off taking any steps before the end of the trademark talks.
A-B said in a statement on Monday that it ended the talks because the company was successful in selling its beer under other trademark on the disputed markets.
"It is no longer necessary for us to have a trademark settlement to develop our Budweiser business in Europe," A-B Chairman Jack Purnell said in a statement.

Anheuser-Busch said it sells its beer under the Budweiser name in 11 European countries and under the "Bud" name in nine other European countries. Both brands have virtually identical labels except for the name, it added.
The limitations had not had a significant impact on A-B's international growth, the U.S. brewer said.
